error.signature: TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'value')

verdict.summary: useContext called in a component that is not wrapped by the corresponding Context.Provider. Returns undefined default value, causing downstream property access errors.

dead_ends.action: Set a default value in createContext() to avoid the error
dead_ends.why_fails: Default values are only used when there is NO Provider ancestor. This masks the structural bug; the component still won't receive real data.

dead_ends.action: Add optional chaining (context?.value) everywhere the context is consumed
dead_ends.why_fails: Treats symptoms not cause. Component renders with no data, producing empty or broken UI.

workarounds.action: Ensure the component tree has the correct Provider wrapping all consumers
workarounds.how: Wrap the consuming component's ancestor with <MyContext.Provider value={...}>. Check that the Provider is in the correct file (often App.tsx or a layout component).

workarounds.action: Create a custom hook that throws a descriptive error when used outside a Provider
workarounds.how: function useMyContext() { const ctx = useContext(MyContext); if (!ctx) throw new Error('useMyContext must be used within MyProvider'); return ctx; }

leads_to.condition: When the Provider is present but passes null or undefined as the value prop

preceded_by.condition: When developer first sees undefined context values and removes the Provider thinking it's unnecessary

frequently_confused_with.distinction: context-provider-missing means the Provider component is not in the tree at all, while context-undefined means the Provider exists but its value prop is undefined
